messages.text:
is there a way to debug Pkg installing large artifacts?
```(PyJl) pkg> add LLVM_full_jll
    Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
   Resolving package versions...
 Downloading artifact: LLVM_full```
Has shown the progress bar of the download up to 100%, and now it's stuck like this since 2 hours... (1.6rc1).

I tried twice, and it always ends up like that.

elements.text: is there a way to debug Pkg installing large artifacts?

(PyJl) pkg> add LLVM_full_jll
    Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
   Resolving package versions...
 Downloading artifact: LLVM_full

Has shown the progress bar of the download up to 100%, and now it's stuck like this since 2 hours... (1.6rc1).

I tried twice, and it always ends up like that.

messages.text: Try `ENV["JULIA_PKG_SERVER"] = ""` before downloading

elements.text: Try
ENV["JULIA_PKG_SERVER"] = ""
before downloading

messages.text: The Pkg servers are pretty stable so it is more likely to be <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Downloads.jl/issues/95|https://github.com/JuliaLang/Downloads.jl/issues/95>

elements.text: The Pkg servers are pretty stable so it is more likely to be

messages.text: Hm, but the artifact downloads are not async and we shouldn't put the same URLs to download like in the MWE there?

elements.text: Hm, but the artifact downloads are not async and we shouldn't put the same URLs to download like in the MWE there?

Ah, you mean

```#!/usr/bin/env bash
#=
exec /path/to/julia-x.x.x/bin/julia --color=yes --startup-file=no -q --compile=min -O0 "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" "$@"
=#
... <julia script here> ...```

messages.text:
I have a package `Omega.jl` , within it there are two subpackages `OmegaCore` and `OmegaTest` ,  Within `OmegaCore` 's runtest I dev OmegaTest as follows:

```using Pkg
Pkg.develop(path = joinpath("..", "..", "OmegaTest"))```
It is failing CI only on Windows with

```Path `..\..\OmegaTest` exists and looks like the correct package. Using existing path.
  Resolving package versions...
ERROR: LoadError: expected package `OmegaTest [1de29bd8]` to exist at path `C:\D:\a\Omega.jl\Omega.jl\OmegaTest`
Stacktrace:
 [1] pkgerror(::String) at C:\buildbot\worker\package_win64\build\usr\share\julia\stdlib\v1.5\Pkg\src\Types.jl:52```
Could anyone tell me what I'm doing wrong?  Do windows paths work differently in this respect?

messages.text:
The reason why they can't coexist is that they have some dependency with conflicting compatibility requirements. The proper solution is track down the conflict, verify that it's fine to widen the compatibility or fix the affected package to work with newer versions of the dependency and make a PR to that affect. The slightly less proper solution is to just do the changes locally in a developed copy of the package, possibly without checking that it works properly.

*Or* don't put everything into one large environment, such as the default environment. If you don't need to use the latest version of Gnuplot together with the latest versions of the other packages, place it in a separate environment. If you do need the latest versions at the same time, see above or wait until someone else has solved the problem.

elements.text: The reason why they can't coexist is that they have some dependency with conflicting compatibility requirements. The proper solution is track down the conflict, verify that it's fine to widen the compatibility or fix the affected package to work with newer versions of the dependency and make a PR to that affect. The slightly less proper solution is to just do the changes locally in a developed copy of the package, possibly without checking that it works properly.
Or

don't put everything into one large environment, such as the default environment. If you don't need to use the latest version of Gnuplot together with the latest versions of the other packages, place it in a separate environment. If you do need the latest versions at the same time, see above or wait until someone else has solved the problem.

attachments.text: In a fresh environment I am trying to install DifferentialEquations and Gnuplot 1.30. If I install DifferentialEquations first, I get the latest copy of the package + all the correct dependencies (particular the dependency [1dea7af3] + OrdinaryDiffEq v5.51.2 which includes some critical bug fixes for me). Then I add Gnuplot by add Gnuplot, but I am guessing due to dependencies it only installs Gnuplot 1.0. The latest version is 1.3. I can force 1.30 by add Gnuplot@1.30 but this severely downgr...

attachments.text: Updated to run w/ 1.5/1.6 below. I say to run because the output is wrong. Pkg.Operations.load_all_deps does not seem to be the correct function to get all dependencies for a package (assuming that’s what Pkg.Operations.load_deps did - it no longer exists). Rather, I believe load_all_deps returns all installed packages in the current environment. julia> length(latest_deps("Revise")) 83 grep "\[\[" ~/.julia/environments/v1.6/Manifest.toml | wc -l 83 Is there a function to return all depe...

messages.text:
On master, there is a nicer (internal) API for it:

```julia> using Pkg, UUIDs

julia> reg = Pkg.Registry.RegistryInstance(joinpath(homedir(), ".julia/registries/General"))
Registry: "General" at "/home/kc/.julia/registries/General":
  uuid: 23338594-aafe-5451-b93e-139f81909106
  repo: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General.git>
  packages: 5201

julia> uuid_dash = UUID("1b08a953-4be3-4667-9a23-3db579824955")
UUID("1b08a953-4be3-4667-9a23-3db579824955")

julia> pkg = reg[uuid_dash]
Pkg.Registry.PkgEntry("D/Dash", "/home/kc/.julia/registries/General", "Dash", UUID("1b08a953-4be3-4667-9a23-3db579824955"), uninit)

julia> info = Pkg.Registry.registry_info(pkg);

julia> info.deps
Dict{Pkg.Versions.VersionRange, Dict{String, UUID}} with 3 entries:
  VersionRange("*")       => Dict("julia"=>UUID("1222c4b2-2114-5bfd-aeef-88e4692bbb3e"))
  VersionRange("0")       => Dict("CodecZlib"=>UUID("944b1d66-785c-5afd-91f1-9de20f533193"), "DashTa…
  VersionRange("0-0.1.0") => Dict("MacroTools"=>UUID("1914dd2f-81c6-5fcd-8719-6d5c9610ff09"))```

messages.text:
This will give you the data in compressed form (the way it is stored in the registry). You can also uncompress (gives you concrete version as keys) this:

```julia> Pkg.Registry.compat_info(info)
Dict{VersionNumber, Dict{UUID, Pkg.Versions.VersionSpec}} with 4 entries:
  v"0.1.2" => Dict(UUID("6ac74813-4b46-53a4-afec-0b5dc9d7885c")=>VersionSpec("0.2"), UUID("cd3eb016-…

  v"0.1.1" => Dict(UUID("6ac74813-4b46-53a4-afec-0b5dc9d7885c")=>VersionSpec("0.2"), UUID("cd3eb016-…
  v"0.1.0" => Dict(UUID("6ac74813-4b46-53a4-afec-0b5dc9d7885c")=>VersionSpec("0.2.1-0.2"), UUID("cd3…```

messages.text: Let's say there's a package, but I need to modify it significantly to make it useful, so I dev it. Is there a recommended way to assign a version number to that private fork?

elements.text: Let's say there's a package, but I need to modify it significantly to make it useful, so I dev it. Is there a recommended way to assign a version number to that private fork?

messages.text: Just change the version in the Project file? Maybe I misunderstand the problem.

elements.text: Just change the version in the Project file? Maybe I misunderstand the problem.

messages.text: Right, but what version should put in for the "private" version? If I just bumped it, the original package may eventually have the same version. The better solution might be to rename the package if I have no intention of upstreaming the modifications.

elements.text: Right, but what version should put in for the "private" version? If I just bumped it, the original package may eventually have the same version. The better solution might be to rename the package if I have no intention of upstreaming the modifications.

messages.text: You can also just change the UUID, so Pkg treats them like different packages

elements.text: You can also just change the UUID, so Pkg treats them like different packages

messages.text: While you `develop` the package it doesn't matter what version you have. If you want to use it as dependency from some other package you have locally or register it in a private registry I would definitely recommend changing the UUID. It's not really necessary to change the name but things become easier and clearer if you do that as well.

elements.text: While you
develop

the package it doesn't matter what version you have. If you want to use it as dependency from some other package you have locally or register it in a private registry I would definitely recommend changing the UUID. It's not really necessary to change the name but things become easier and clearer if you do that as well.

messages.text: Is it correctly understood that a Manifest entry like <https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1/toml-files/#Added-package-by-branch> doesn’t tell you which *exact* version of the package is being used since “master” might be (and usually is) evolving?

elements.text: Is it correctly understood that a Manifest entry like
doesn’t tell you which
exact
version of the package is being used since “master” might be (and usually is) evolving?

messages.text: It does tell you because it also stores the git-tree-sha (which is a content hash). The branch that gets put into the Manifest is used when you update, whereby the latest commit from that branch is updated to.

elements.text: It does tell you because it also stores the git-tree-sha (which is a content hash). The branch that gets put into the Manifest is used when you update, whereby the latest commit from that branch is updated to.

messages.text: How do I find the commit sha based on the tree sha?

elements.text: How do I find the commit sha based on the tree sha?

messages.text: Maybe something like this: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/TagBot/blob/afea108e2cd6116e3cf366b55f116b8c257ae0f2/tagbot/action/git.py#L80|https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/TagBot/blob/afea108e2cd6116e3cf366b55f116b8c257ae0f2/tagbot/action/git.py#L80>

elements.text: Maybe something like this:
https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/TagBot/blob/afea108e2cd6116e3cf366b55f116b8c257ae0f2/tagbot/action/git.py#L80
